definition: S or s is the nineteenth letter of the English alphabet
for South, Saturday and Sunday

senses.definition: ' An s can be added to numbers, letters and some abbreviations to form plurals, for example '
example: he gives, '[cf2]she gives, '[cf2]it gives, '[cf2]he catches
house becomes '[cf2]houses, and '[cf2]glass becomes '[cf2]glasses
I lived through the 1960s
note: ... NOTE that this is the standard usage, but 's is sometimes still used: 'the 1960's.

senses.definition: ' get the sack'  In informal language, if you say that someone gets the sack or is given the sack, you mean that their employer tells them that they cannot work for them any longer.  The employer dismisses them.
example: The boss sacked Li Ling yesterday[j4]she used to spend the whole day chatting to friends on the phone

Don't be late again for work or you might get the sack. [j33] My boss gave me the sack because he thought I was lazy, but I'm not.  4 ' hit the sack'  '[cf2] In informal language, if you say you hit the sack, you mean you go to bed.  [cf2]I'm tired.  I think I'll hit the sack
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun sacking'

senses.definition: ' safe and sound'  If you say that someone or something is safe and sound, you mean that they have been in a situation that could have been dangerous and are now in a secure place where they cannot be harmed.
example: You can use the drill now[j4]it's quite safe. [j33] These stairs are not safe for the elderly. [j33] Is it safe to leave my bag here? [j33] Joe's a safe driver
I keep my will in the wall safe. [j33] My money and jewellery are in the safe
It's a very good hospital so you'll be in safe hands
I don't think it will rain but I'll take an umbrella just to be on the safe side[j4] I hate getting wet
The police rescue squad found the lost hikers safe and sound after their overnight ordeal
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb safely' Drive safely!  Bye now!   The parcel arrived safely.[j35]'noun safety' Parents are responsible for their children's safety.

senses.definition: ' take something with a grain of salt'  If you take something that someone says with a grain of salt, you do not accept it as being completely true.

Jo never spends any money[j4]she must have salted away a fortune by now
Marie might be a bit rough, but she's the salt of the earth[j4]she'd do anything to help you

example: She was seconded to the Prime Minister's office to complete the report. 7' second thoughts' '[cf2] If you have second thoughts about something, you start to doubt that you made the right decision. [cf2]Judy has postponed the wedding as she's having second thoughts about Otto
He gave her his car keys, without a second thought
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb secondly' Firstly, I don't have time and secondly, I'm not interested.

[cf2]Next year Jane finishes primary and begins secondary school

senses.definition: ' in secret'  If someone does something in secret, they do it without anyone else knowing about it.

Grandfather's desk has a secret drawer

definition: If part of a plant or animal secretes a liquid, it produces it.

definition: A sect is a group of people who have separated from a larger religious group because their views and beliefs have changed in some way
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective sectarian'

senses.definition: ' A section is a picture of how something would look inside if you cut through it.

note: ... A SIMILAR WORD for sense 2 is cross-section.

definition: If something is secular, it has nothing to do with religion or churches.

senses.definition: 1' see to it that' If you see to it that something happens, you make sure it happens.
example: Can't you see anything without your glasses? [j33] I'd like to see the pyramids of Egypt
I see his rudeness differently. [j33] I see what you mean. [j33] I think I see what's upsetting you

Can I see Bill's letter? [j33] See who's at the door. 4 ' '[cf2]verb If you see a movie or television show, you watch it.  [cf2]Have you seen the film that won the prize? 5 ' '[cf2]verb If you see that something is the case, you understand that it is the case after looking at it and thinking about it.  [cf2]I can see you're tired. [j33] I see that prices are rising. [j33] They didn't want us to see their failures

'Mum, can I borrow your car to go to the party tonight?'  'I'll see
I'll see you to your car
I could see right through her efforts to win me over
I'll see to dinner tonight. [j33] That's a bad cut[j4]you should get a doctor to see to it
Ross is busy.  See to it that no-one disturbs him. [j33] I'll see to it that the guests have something to drink
2' see you later'  In informal spoken language, see you or see you later means 'goodbye'

example: The party was great but I feel a bit seedy this morning

example: We're seeking accommodation for two nights. [j33] The workers are seeking a pay rise of $30 a week. [j33] I suggest you seek professional help
He sought to improve his fitness by training in the gym

definition: If something seems to be a certain way, it appears or looks to be that way.
example: She seems to have put on weight. [j33] The noise seemed to come from next door

definition: If something seeps, it slowly leaks or drips away.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun seepage'
example: The rain seeped through Vyt's waterproof coat. [j33] The blood seeped from the wound

definition: A seesaw is a device for children to play on
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb seesaw'
example: It consists of a long board that's fixed in the middle.  Two children sit at opposite ends of the seesaw and as one goes up, the other goes down

definition: A segment of something is one section or part of it.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun segmentation'
example: I've already seen that segment of the film. [j33] She offered me a segment of her mandarin

definition: If a person or thing is segregated, they are kept apart from the rest of a group.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun segregation'
example: They segregated the sick children at the camp so that no-one else got ill

senses.definition: ' If you seize something, you take hold of it quickly and firmly.  You grab it.
example: He seized the bag and ran off. [j33] ...seize an opportunity. 2 ' '[cf2] If something seizes, it stops working.  [cf2]Without oil the engine will seize
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun seizure' He suffered a heart seizure.

senses.definition: ' A select group of people or things is a small group that has been carefully chosen.
example: She selected a biography for her mother's present. [j33] He selects his friends very carefully
The performance was watched by a select panel of judges. [j33] Only select parts of the interview were shown
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective See selective'.[j35]'noun selection' He has an interesting selection of friends.

definition: If you are selective, you choose things carefully.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb selectively'
example: She's very selective about what she wears. [j33] ...a selective school

definition: Your self is you
example: It is all the things that make you what you are, such as your body, your mind, your character, and your intelligence

definition: 'times,0'[cp8.5]self-[j24]sent[j17]d' If you are self-centred, you think only about yourself.  You are not concerned with other people's wants or needs.
example: He's too self-centred to notice that he's offended her. [j33] His self-centred attitude has made him unpopular

definition: 'times,0'[cp8.5]self-[j24]k[j16]nf[j17]d[j17]ns' If you are self-confident, you have confidence in yourself. You are sure of your own value and ability.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun self-confidence'
example: Jo is very self-confident for such a young boy

definition: 'times,0'[cp8
example: 5]self-[j24]k[j16]n[j14][j17]s' If you are self-conscious, you are shy.  You lack faith in your own abilities and you think that people are looking at you critically

definition: 'times,0'[cp8.5]self-d[j17][j24]fens' Self-defence is the use of special physical skills to protect yourself when someone attacks you.
example: The accused claimed that he had acted in self-defence

definition: If you are selfish, you only care about yourself.  You do what you want without considering others.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun selfishness'
example: Gregor is so selfish[j4] he ate the whole box of chocolates

definition: 'times,0'[cp8

definition: A serviette is a piece of material or paper used to wipe your hands or your mouth during a meal

definition: A serving of food is an amount that is enough for one person.

definition: A serving spoon is a large spoon which is used for putting food on people's plates

senses.definition: 9' set up'  If you set someone up with something, you provide them with it.
example: Ask the electrician to set the power box into the side wall.  18 ' set off'  '[cf2] If you set off something, you cause it to explode or go off. [cf2]We hope they will not set off any more bombs. [j33] Be careful not to set off the burglar alarm when you go into the house. '  '[cf2] If you set off on a journey, you begin it.  [cf2]We hope to set off bright and early tomorrow morning. [j33] They're setting off on a new life together

His parents set him up with a car for his birthday. '   (a) '[cf2] In informal language, if someone sets you up, they try to make you take the blame for something that you haven't done. [j33] ...set up a roadblock

senses.definition: ' If you settle someone, you calm them or make them comfortable.
example: Her head settled into the soft pillows. [j33] The sediment from the red wine needs to settle
Haven't you two settled your argument yet? [j33] The case has been settled
' If you settle your affairs or your business, you put them in order.  You organise them
' If you settle a bill or an account, you pay it
The family finally settled in Wollongong
He settled the children by reading them a story
' settle down'  If you settle down to something, you begin to work hard on what you are doing.  You don't let yourself be distracted
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun settlement' A small settlement has sprung up in what used to be a farming area.[j35] 'noun settler'

comment: verb forms shakes, shook, shaken, shaking

senses.definition: ' shake off'  If you shake off someone or something, you get rid of them.
example: Put the oil and vinegar in a bottle and shake it thoroughly
The windows shook when the plane flew by. [j33] The girls were shaking with laughter
' If your voice shakes, it trembles with strong feeling such as anger, fear or pity
The old man looked quite shaken by his fall
The war shook his faith in human nature

He thinks he's a champion swimmer but he's no great shakes. 7 ' shake hands'  '[cf2] If you shake hands with someone, you take their right hand in yours and move it up and down several times.  It is a custom to do this when meeting people for the first time, when saying goodbye to them or when congratulating them for something
I managed to shake off the flu. [j33] Shake the mud off your clothes
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun shake' Give the bottle a shake before you open it.[j35]'adjective shaky'

senses.definition: ' If someone or something such as an idea is shallow, they aren't complex or deep.  They do not show much thought about important matters.
example: Make sure Sally stays in the shallow end of the pool. [j33] ...a shallow grave
He's so shallow, all he ever talks about is cars and sport

definition: If something is a sham, it is not what it seems to be.
note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is fraud.  [j32] ... WORD FAMILY 'verb sham (shams, shammed, shamming)' She shammed illness.
example: He's got his arm in a sling but it's a sham to avoid work

senses.definition: ' put to shame'  If something puts you to shame, it makes you feel bad because it is so superior to you or to what you have done.
example: She hit the dog and then hung her head in shame
What a shame it's raining. [j33] It's a shame you didn't buy that house
Her generosity puts me to shame. 5 ' shame on you'  '[cf2] If you say shame on you to someone, you mean that they should be ashamed of themselves for doing a particular thing
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective See ashamed'.[j35]'verb shame' He shamed her into apologising.[j35]'adjective shameful' He embarrassed us by his shameful beha~ [chviour.[j35]'adjective shameless' She's a shameless liar.  He's shameless about cheating his customers.

senses.definition: ' A shanty is a small roughly built hut which poor people live in.
example: The whole family of ten was crowded into an old tin shanty on the outskirts of the town. 2 ' '[cf2]noun A shanty is also a song which sailors used to sing when they were working on board a ship

senses.definition: ' shape up well'  In informal language, if you say that something or someone is shaping up well, you mean that they are developing well.
example: 'What shape is your swimming pool?'  'It's a kind of pear shape.' 2 ' '[cf2]verb If you shape something, you give it a particular form.  [cf2]First he shaped the clay into a ball. 3 ' in any shape or form'  '[cf2] If you say something is unacceptable in any shape or form, you mean that you would reject it under any circumstances. [cf2]He doesn't like cabbage in any shape or form
She's really in shape from swimming every day
If you are out of shape, you are unhealthy and physically unfit.  [cf2]I'm too out of shape to run up these stairs
Georgio told his son to shape up or else leave home
The young cricketers are shaping up well
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective shapeless' [j35]'adjective shapely' Anna's got nice shapely legs.

senses.definition: ' A share is one of the equal parts into which the ownership of a company is divided. These shares can be traded.
example: Fatimah hates sharing a bedroom with her sister because she's so untidy
The family shares the cooking and the household chores
I bought some  shares at $4.50 and sold them at $6.00
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See shareholder'.

senses.definition: ' If you say that something will happen at 8 p.m. sharp, it means that it will begin at exactly 8 p.m. 10a ' '
example: I need a sharp pencil for this fine work. [j33] ...a sharp needle. 3 ' '[cf2]adjective If something such as a picture or outline is sharp, it is very clear and distinct, which makes it easy to see.  [cf2]You'll get a sharper picture if you turn this knob
She stayed sharp well into her old age
' If you say that someone has sharp eyes or ears or a sharp nose, you mean that their sight or hearing or sense of smell is very good
Alfredo was knocked out by a sharp blow to the head
She was half frozen by the sharp wind. [j33] I felt a sharp pain in the lower back. [j33] ...sharp pangs of jealousy
There's been a sharp change in the temperature. [j33] ...a sharp bend in the road
noun In music, a sharp is a note that is a semitone higher in pitch than a note of the same name, for example C sharp is a semitone higher than C
b' In music, a sharp is also the musical sign (#), which raises a note by a semitone
note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is flat.   11' 'adjective If food has a sharp taste, it is strong ~and sometimes bitter.  I bought a sharp cheese.   ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See sharpener'.[j35]'verb sharpen' I sharpen my kitchen knives regularly.[j35] 'adverb sharply' He turned sharply into a side street.   'Stop that,' he said sharply.

Alfredo was knocked out by a sharp blow to the head
She was half frozen by the sharp wind. [j33] I felt a sharp pain in the lower back. [j33] ...sharp pangs of jealousy
There's been a sharp change in the temperature. [j33] ...a sharp bend in the road
noun In music, a sharp is a note that is a semitone higher in pitch than a note of the same name, for example C sharp is a semitone higher than C
b' In music, a sharp is also the musical sign (#), which raises a note by a semitone
note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is flat.   11' 'adjective If food has a sharp taste, it is strong ~and sometimes bitter.  I bought a sharp cheese.   ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See sharpener'.[j35]'verb sharpen' I sharpen my kitchen knives regularly.[j35] 'adverb sharply' He turned sharply into a side street.   'Stop that,' he said sharply.

senses.definition: ' shorts'  (a) Shorts are short trousers that come to just above the knee.
example: He is only here for a short visit. [j33] ...a short story
The oldest brother is the shortest in the family
I wanted to make ~a skirt with this material but it's about 10 centimetres too short. [j33] ...a dollar short

It was short and sweet[j4] he simply gave me the sack.  7 ' short cut'  '[cf2] A short cut is a quicker way of getting somewhere than the usual route, or a quicker method of doing something than the way it is usually done. example: I slipped on the dining room rug and fell

I'll just slip up the street and buy some milk
Nobody saw Felix slip the drug into Carla's drink
Serge made a small slip today[j4]he gave one customer the wrong amount of change
She let slip that she was going to leave her job
' let things slip'  If someone lets things slip, they do not do enough of what they ought to do.  They ~neglect it
' slip your memory'  If you say that something has slipped your memory, you mean that you have forgotten about it

Bill enjoys knitting in his spare time
Nobody was spared[j4]women and ~children were massacred along with the men. [j33] The developers spared nothing but a few old trees when they were clearing the property
Getting a lift to the airport spared me the inconvenience of catching a bus with all my luggage. [j33] 'The accident was particularly gruesome.'  'Spare me the details, please
I'm making a cake but I've run out of eggs.  Can you spare me a few? [j33] The boss managed to spare me some time in the afternoon to discuss my proposal
I need some spare parts for the car
Denise is the only person I know who has ever come home from a holiday with money to spare. [j33] He says he has little time to spare for his children

senses.definition: ' split up'  If two people split up, they stop living together. They each go their own way. '  '
example: Here's $20[j4]split it between the two of you. [j33] Let's split into small groups for a discussion of the topic
The book split right along the spine. [j33] We split the logs with an axe
The board split over who should be appointed the new director. [j33] The contro~ versy has split the party
There's a split between what he's thinking and how he expresses it in words. [j33] He's not aware of the split between fantasy and reality
It's a good cabinet[j4]the split at the back can be easily fixed
If you say that something happened in a split second, you mean that it happened very quickly or in a very small amount of time
If a group of people split up, they go away in different directions.  [cf2]The search party split up to cover a larger territory. [j33] Our group split up in Alice Springs and met up again in Darwin
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun split' The controversy caused a split in the party.

senses.definition: ' spot check'  A spot check on something is a sudden, unplanned inspection of it or an inspection of a small number of items at random.
example: I was on the spot when the fire started. '   (b) '[cf2] If you do something on the spot, you do it right away.  [cf2]They saw a house they liked and made up their minds on the spot. '   (c) '[cf2] If someone puts you on the spot, they put you in a difficult or embarrassing situation.  [cf2]She put me on the spot by asking me in front of everyone why I didn't like her
When a health inspector arrived for a spot check of the premises, we were a bit worried. [j33] The manufacturer did a spot check and found that some of the brakes were faulty
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective See spotted'.[j35]'adjective See spotty'.

' for sexually transmitted disease, which is any disease that you can get from someone by having sex with them

definition: If you are steadfast in something you do, you believe it is right to do it and do not let anything make you change it or give it up.
example: They are steadfast supporters of their local club. [j33] Jenny is a steadfast friend

senses.definition: ' If someone is steady, they are calm.  They do not look excited or nervous.
example: Erik's progress in class is steady. [j33] We've had some good, steady rain. ~[j33] There's been a steady growth in the number of students each year. [j33] He gets a steady income from gardening

The baby is looking steadier on her legs now. [j33] This ladder isn't steady. b ' '[cf2]verb If you steady something, you stop it from moving.  [cf2]He took hold of her elbow to steady her. 3 ' '[cf2]adjective Work that is steady is likely to continue for a long time.  [cf2]Brian doesn't have a steady job; he survives on occasional contract work
Kevin is a steady worker.  We need more people like him
Her voice was steady despite the anger she felt
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb steadily' It rained steadily all day.

senses.definition: ' Steak is beef that has been cut into slices.  You can refer to a slice of beef as a steak.
example: Get some lean steak for the barbecue.  2 ' '[cf2]noun You can also refer to a slice of any other kind of meat as a steak.  [cf2]...ham steak. [j33] ...tuna steaks

senses.definition: ' If you steal somewhere, you go there very quietly, trying not to be noticed.
example: Joe got caught stealing someone's handbag
He stole up on us out of the dark. [j33] I'm going to steal away at interval
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun stealing' Stealing is a criminal offence.

senses.definition: ' run out of steam'  In informal language, if you say that someone has run out of steam, you mean that they have slowed down or stopped what they were doing. ~ They have no energy left.
example: Open the window to let the steam out of the bathroom
The wet road was steaming in the sun
I'll steam the vegetables and fry the meat
After work he lets off steam by playing squash
Jan started to catalogue her library but she ran out of steam
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun steamer' ...a rice steamer.[j35] 'adjective steamy'

example: It is used in heavy industry and for making kitchen utensils such as pans and knives

senses.definition: ' If you steer a vehicle, you make it go in the direction you want it to go using the steering wheel.
example: He steered the car into the garage. 2 ' '[cf2]verb If you steer someone or something, you cause them to go in a particular direction.  [cf2]He found himself being steered towards the door. [j33] Try and steer the conversation onto a different topic
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun steering' The steering in my car is a bit stiff.

definition: The steering wheel in a vehicle is the wheel which the driver holds when driving it
note: ... SEE THE PICTURE at car.

senses.definition: ' If you stem something that is growing or spreading, you stop it.
senses.rest: H@w d@Es thE g@vErnmEnt i:ntEnd t@ stEm thE ri:sE i:n u:nEmpl@ymEnt?
example: The seedling died when it was broken off at the stem
' The stem of an object such as a vase is the thin central part which joins the base to the top
luck is the stem of '[cf2]lucky and '[cf2]luckily
Their financial problems stem from poor planning
She stemmed the flow of water by turning it off at the main

definition: A stenographer is a shorthand typist
example: They write down what someone is saying in shorthand and then type it out in full

senses.definition: ' step up'  If you step up something, you increase it.
example: We've stepped up our efforts to control the virus. [j33] They're stepping up production to keep up with the demand for the product
0' watch your step' In informal language, if you tell someone to watch their step, you are warning them to be more careful about how they behave in the future

example: noun A stepladder is a type of ladder

definition: Someone's step~ mother is the woman who has married their father after their mother has died or divorced their father

senses.definition: ' A stereo is a machine for playing music through two speakers.  2 ' '
example: noun Stereo is the name given to the system of playing music through two speakers.  It gives the listener the impression that the sound is being produced all around them.  [cf2]I first heard the song on radio, then bought the CD[j4]it sounds even better in stereo
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective stereo' ...stereo equipment.

senses.definition: ' If something is sterile, it is free from germs.
example: She boiled the baby's bottle to make it sterile
' If a person or animal is sterile, they are unable to reproduce.  They are infertile
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun sterility'

example: She boiled the baby's bottle to make it sterile
' If a person or animal is sterile, they are unable to reproduce.  They are infertile
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun sterility'

senses.definition: ' If you sterilise some~ thing, you make it free of germs, often by boiling it.
example: All surgical instruments must be sterilised after use
' If a person or animal is sterilised, they have an operation which makes them unable to reproduce
note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this is sterilize.

example: Her father was a stern man who always expected to be obeyed

senses.definition: ' in a stew'  In informal language, if you say someone is in a stew, you mean that they are anxious about something.
example: I'll stew the plums to make jam

senses.definition: 2' the sticks'  In informal language, the sticks refers to the country or to a small town far from the cities.
example: The boys were gathering sticks for the fire
...a stick of celery. [j33] ...a carrot stick. [j33] ...a stick of dynamite
Someone stuck a knife between his ribs. [j33] Don't stick your elbow into me
I tried to stick the broken pieces of the vase together. [j33] The note was stuck to the door with a tack
The clay kept sticking to her fingers. [j33] Make sure the custard doesn't stick to the bottom of the pan
The door is sticking
Just stick the book on the table

Why don't you stick around until the others arrive? 9 ' stick at'  '[cf2] If you stick at something you are doing, you keep doing it even though it may be difficult. [cf2]Don't give up now[j4]if you stick at it you'll succeed
Andrea's friends stuck by her while she was going through a hard time
She stuck up for me against the other teachers
They used to live in the city but now they're out in the sticks
3' the wrong end of the stick' In informal language, if you say that someone's got the wrong end of the stick, you mean that they have totally misunderstood something
note: [j34] ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective See sticky[j35]'noun stickiness'

senses.definition: ' In informal language, if you are bored, worried or scared stiff, you are extremely bored, worried or scared.
example: This stiff collar digs into my neck
The hinges are too stiff for the door to open wide
I played squash for two hours yesterday and today I'm stiff all over
He greeted me with a stiff nod and then ignored me for the rest of the evening. [j33] She sounded stiff and formal on the phone
There are stiff penalties for speeding. [j33] He had to shut down the business because the competition was too stiff
We were bored stiff by the stories about his hunting trips. [j33] She's worried stiff about her exam results
' In informal language, a stiff is a dead body
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb stiffen' Do you use starch to stiffen your collars?[j35]'adverb stiffly' He moved stiffly, as if in pain.[j35]'noun stiffness'

senses.definition: ' You use still with descriptive words to show that something has even more of a particular quality than something else.
example: He's still busy writing the report. [j33] Do you still live in Brisbane? [j33] Rodney is still a baby. [j33] There's still some milk in the fridge. 2 ' '[cf2]adverb If something that has not yet happened could still happen, it is possible that it will happen in the future.  [cf2]He still hasn't decided what to do. [j33] It might still rain in the evening. [j33] It's not too late[j4] there's still time to send in an application

You sit still while I make the tea. [j33] Keep your head still while I cut your hair. [j33] His hands were quite still in his lap. 4 ' '[cf2]adjective If something stays still, it is quiet and shows no sign of activity or movement.  [cf2]The trees along the bank were reflected in the still water of the lake. [j33] Distant sounds could be heard in the still night
He's a naughty boy but I still love him
Bill is tall but his brother Mark is taller still
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb still' She managed to still the flow of blood by packing it with cotton wool.[j35]'noun stillness' The sound of a few birds disturbed the stillness of the night.

example: The teacher played them tapes to stimulate an interest in music. [j33] I feel stimulated by the lively atmosphere in this city

senses.definition: ' If something causes a stir, it excites, angers or shocks people.
example: Stir the paint well before use. [j33] Could you please stir the soup
The baby stirred briefly and then went back to sleep
The leaves were stirring in the breeze
The audience was stirred by the brilliance of the performance. [j33] The appalling conditions in the hospital stirred him deeply and he decided to do something about it
Don't listen to Tom, he's just stirring
His purple suit caused quite a stir. [j33] Julie created a stir with the announcement of her resignation
' stir up'  If you stir up trouble or stir up a feeling, you make trouble or make people have that feeling
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun stirrer' Don't listen to Tom[j4] he's a stirrer.[j35]'adjective stirring' ...a stirring speech.  ...a stirring performance.

senses.definition: ' You can refer to a piece of news in a newspaper, magazine, or broadcast as a story.
example: Children love fairy stories. [j33] Do you know the story of Peter and the Wolf? [j33] ~ We're reading some short stories by Chekhov this semester. [j33] ...bedtime stories
The old man told us the story of his life in the outback. [j33] The story of the Australian wheat industry is presented in this brochure
Don't believe a word of it[j4]he's telling stories again

The lead story this morning is about global warming. [j33] A story about the royal divorce made front page news again. 5 ' to cut a long story short'  '[cf2] You say to cut a long story short to show that you are not going to give any more details about a situation, but just state the outcome.  [cf2]My health has been rather bad lately[j4]I've had stomach pains and nausea, but to cut a long story short I have to go to hospital for an operation
' tall story'  A tall story is a story that is very exaggerated or untrue

senses.definition: ' A superficial similarity or likeness is one that is obvious when you look at something rather carelessly or quickly.
example: It's a superficial adventure story I read to pass the time. [j33] She acts like an expert but has only a superficial knowledge of the subject
The victim was treated for superficial wounds and allowed to go home. [j33] The superficial scratches on the table are nothing to worry about

definition: In grammar, the superlative form of an adjective indicates that the thing being described has more of a certain attribute than anything else.
example: In the sentence, 'Bill Gates is the richest man in the world', the word 'richest' is in the superlative form

definition: A supermarket is a large self-service shop where you can buy all kinds of food and household items.
example: We buy most of our groceries at the supermarket

definition: If someone is superstitious, they have beliefs that are not based on fact or reason.  This makes them afraid of certain bad events or of things that are mysterious or unknown to them.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun superstition'
example: Lauren is superstitious about walking under ladders[j4]she thinks it brings bad luck

definition: If you supervise an activity, or the people involved in it, you make sure that everything is done properly.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun supervision' [j35]'noun supervisor'
example: Who will supervise the class while the teacher is away? [j33] Supervising the construction of the bridge was an enormous task

definition: Supper is a very light meal such as a biscuit and cup of tea  that you have late in the evening or just before you go to bed.
note: ... COMPARE THIS with dinner.
example: We had supper at a cafe after the show

definition: If someone or something is supple, they bend easily.
example: The supple dancer touched the ground behind his heels. [j33] Pick the willow stems while they are still supple

senses.definition: ' If you supplement something, you add to it or increase it so that it will be better for you or more useful to you.
example: The child needs a vitamin supplement to stop her getting colds. [j33] The casual job is a supplement to his normal income. 2 ' '[cf2]noun A supplement in a newspaper or magazine is an extra section that is added to it
You should supplement your meals with iron tablets
note: [j34] ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective supplementary'

comment: verb forms supplies, supplied, supplying; '[cf2]plural form supplies

senses.definition: ' supplies'  Supplies are the items such as food and equipment that are needed by a group of people who go on a rather difficult journey.
example: The factory has a contract to supply parts to a car manufacturer. [j33] They supply the hospital with linen
He keeps a large supply of chewing gum in the top drawer of his desk. [j33] The water supply in the dam is very low because of the drought
He needs a regular supply of insulin for his diabetes
' in short supply'  If something is in short supply, there isn't enough of it available
Food supplies for the climb were beginning to run out
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun supplier'

senses.definition: ' If you support yourself, you hold onto something in order to prevent yourself from falling over.
example: Can this little shelf support all those heavy books? [j33] That chair's too old and shaky to support the weight of an adult
She is joining the party to support them in the next election
Jenny had to support her mother and sister when she left school
Janice had no-one to support her through her grief when her mother died
I slipped in the bath, but managed to support myself by grabbing the towel rail
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun support' He was a great support to his sister when she was sick.[j35]'noun supporter' Carlos is a keen supporter of his local football club.

senses.definition: ' supposing'  You say suppose or supposing when you're wondering what would happen if a particular situation arose or if a particular event occurred.
senses.rest: Su:pp@si:ng thEy d@n't rEfu:nd y@u:r m@nEy, wha:t wi:ll y@u: d@?
example: What do you suppose is the matter with Rosemary today? [j33] Kevin didn't know where his wife was, but supposed she was with her mother
I suppose your daughter will start school next year. [j33] 'Why did he leave so early?'  'He wasn't feeling well, I suppose
Don't quit your job yet[j4] suppose you can't find another one soon
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun supposition' He acted on the supposition that she would come home soon.

senses.definition: ' If a group of people suppress an activity, they prevent it from happen~ ing.
example: He's back at work after his supposed illness. [j33] The supposed building inspector was really a burglar

Children are supposed to need more sleep than adults. [j33] It's supposed to be the best restaurant in the area[j4]let's try it. '   (b) '[cf2] If you say that something is supposed to be done, you mean that it ought to be done, because of some rule, requirement, or custom.  [cf2]According to the building contract they're supposed to finish the house by June. [j33] How many of these pills am I supposed to take? [j33] Excuse me, you're not supposed to eat in the library. '   (c) '[cf2] If you say that something is supposed to happen, you mean that someone intended it to happen, but it may not happen.  [cf2]It's supposed to be easy to assemble, but I've been struggling with it for an hour. [j33] I wonder where he is[j4]he's supposed to have arrived by now. [j33] How is this gadget supposed to work?  ~--suppress 'times,0'[cp8.5]s[j17][j24]pres'[cp8

The demonstration was quickly suppressed by the police. [j33] Tear gas was used to suppress the rioters. 2 ' '[cf2]verb If someone suppresses information, they prevent it from becoming known.  [cf2]The editor of the paper suppressed the news report on legal grounds. 3 ' '[cf2]verb If you suppress a feeling, you prevent yourself from showing or expressing it.  [cf2]Henry tried to suppress a smile and then burst out laughing. [j33] Talk to him about the problem[j4]don't keep suppressing your anger
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun suppression'

senses.definition: ' Supreme also means 'great' or 'outstanding'.

note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun supremacy' His supremacy in chess has never been challenged.[j35]'adverb supremely'

senses.definition: ' make sure'   (a) If you make sure that something is as you want it to be, you check or find out if it is definitely ~that way.
example: I'm sure it's going to rain. [j33] Are you sure you can do it? [j33] We're not sure of the reliability of this data. [j33] I'm not sure I like that idea. [j33] Jane's not sure she likes her job any more
If you study a little every day you can be sure of passing the test. [j33] Thanks to the rain we can be sure of a good crop this year

It's sure to rain today. [j33] They're sure to ask you why you want the job, so think of a good answer. 4 ' '[cf2]adjective If you are sure of yourself, you are very confident that you are right or that you can do certain things.  [cf2]He's been much more sure of himself since he left home
'Can I please borrow your car?'  'Sure

Can you make sure I've turned off the iron, please. [j33] He made sure there were no cars in sight before he did the U-turn. '   (b) '[cf2] If you make sure that something happens, you do something so that it will definitely happen.  You ensure that it happens.  [cf2]Jim made sure the staff had plenty to do while he was away[j4]he gave them a new project to work on. [j33] Make sure the dough rises before you bake it
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun sureness'

senses.definition: ' If something surfaces, it appears again after a period of being hidden.
example: Don't put hot things on the surface of the table. [j33] This polish is suitable for all wooden surfaces
The job looks straightforward on the surface but in fact takes a lot of careful thought. [j33] The child's learning difficulties didn't come to the surface until she started school
